Laboratory of Organic Chemistry Department of Chemistry Central University of Punjab Bathinda 151401 India An efficient multicomponent decarboxylative coupling of 2-aminopyridines, aldehydes and alkynoic acids for the synthesis of imidazo[1,2-a]pyridines was developed using recyclable chitosan-supported copper (chit@CuSO4) as a heterogeneous catalyst. Computational and experimental evidence revealed that in situ generated propargylamine undergoes cyclization to the desired imidazopyridine via prototropic isomerization involving allene type intermediates. Control experiments on isolated propargylamine demonstrated that cyclization could proceed without any metal catalyst. In literature, the cyclization step is assumed to be facilitated by metal catalyst and experimental proof for the involvement of actual intermediates is not available. The synthesized imidazopyridines were further evaluated for antiproliferative activity against human neuroblastoma cells (SHSY-5Y) using MTT assay. Multicomponent reactions (MCRs) with tandem sequences can construct structurally complex and functionally diverse molecules in a single step which could be of high value in drug discovery programmes for the hunt of new therapeutics possessing improved or novel pharmacological potential [7–12]. It would be beneficial but challenging if abundant and stable surrogates besides efficient and recyclable heterogeneous catalytic systems could be employed in MCRs. Imidazo[1,2-a]pyridine [13–23], is a privileged structural motif of many natural products, drug molecules and therapeutic leads with a broad range of biological activities, including antifungal, anti-inflammatory, antitumor, antiviral, antiulcer, antibacterial, antiprotozoal, antipyretic, analgesic and hypnoselective. Several drugs containing the imidazo[1,2-a]pyridine moiety have been introduced in the market such as zolpidem, alpidem, necopidem, saripidem, zolimidine, miroprofen and olprinone (Fig. 1 ). Owing to the immense biological potential of the scaffold, the development of benign protocols for synthesizing diversely substituted imidazo[1,2-a]pyridines is highly desired. Consequently, various multicomponent approaches have been developed including the three-component coupling of 2-aminopyridines, aldehydes and isonitriles/nitroalkanes/trimethylsilyl cyanides/alkynes [24–38]. In particular, the coupling of 2-aminopyridines, aldehydes and terminal alkynes has gained significant attention for the synthesis of imidazopyridines [27–38]. Several copper based catalytic systems such as CuCl/Cu(OTf)2 [27], CuSO4/TsOH [28], CuSO4·5H2O/sodium ascorbate [29], CuI/NaHSO4.SiO2 [30], Cu2O-graphene oxide [31], have been employed. Despite many successes, terminal alkynes (susceptible to polymerization) need special attention for their storage/handling and require an inert atmosphere. Recently, Chen and Li explored CaC2 as an alternative source of alkyne (gaseous acetylene) for the multicomponent synthesis of imidazopyridines [39]. Decarboxylative coupling has emerged as a vital tool for contemporary organic synthesis as a variety of carboxylic acids are commercially available, stable and easy to handle [40–44]. In this context, using alkynoic acids as stable surrogates for alkynes (via in situ decarboxylation) represents an attractive alternative for the efficient synthesis of imidazo[1,2-a]pyridines. Only a few protocols are reported for the decarboxylative coupling of 2-aminopyridines, aldehydes and alkynoic acids, which mainly employ CuI-Cu(OTf)2 catalytic combination [45,46]. Despite the significant catalytic activity, there is a scope for further improvement such as mild reaction conditions using efficient and recyclable catalytic systems. In general, (i) the use of non-recyclable metal-based catalysts often produce a significant amount of metallic waste after completion of reaction (ii) also, the possibility of contamination/trapping of even traces of metal impurity in the final product could be potentially harmful, particularly in pharmaceutical applications. Ananikov and Egorova [47,48], revealed that copper and nickel salts (supposed to be cheap and benign) may be more toxic as compared to heavy metal complexes of Pd, Pt or Au. Thus, to minimize chemical and metal waste, there is a constant pressure on chemical and pharmaceutical industries to develop and explore recyclable heterogeneous metal catalysts. The MCR of aldehyde, amine and alkyne or alkynoic acid is reported to proceed via 5-exo-dig cyclization of in situ generated propargylamine (A3-type product) (Scheme 1 ). The metal catalyst is assumed to coordinate with carbon-carbon triple bond of propargylamine and facilitates the cyclization via species I (Scheme 1). Our DFT/mechanistic study revealed that the propargylamine cyclization step proceeds via involvement of allene types of intermediates. Control experiments on propargylamine demonstrated that this cyclization can proceed without using any metal catalyst. Also, DFT study showed that the cyclic species I formation is energetically not favored. In continuation of our work on the development of benign methodologies [49–54], we herein disclose chit@CuSO4 (CuSO4 supported on chitosan) as an efficient heterogeneous catalyst for the decarboxylative coupling of 2-aminopyridines, aldehydes and alkynoic acids and its mechanistic studies. The synthesized compounds were further evaluated for antiproliferative activity against human neuroblastoma cells (SHSY-5Y) using MTT assay. Compounds 3-benzyl-2-(4-chlorophenyl)imidazo[1,2-a]pyridine (4a) and 3-benzyl-2-(4-isopropylphenyl)imidazo[1,2-a]pyridine (4d) were most potent in the series with IC50 values of 7.63 µM and 9.14 µM respectively. 2 Results and discussion Taking leads from our earlier work [49–51], we got interested in exploring chit@Cu catalysts (chit@CuI, chit@CuCl, chit@CuSO4, chit@Cu(OAc)2 and chit@CuBr) for the multicomponent decarboxylative coupling of 2-aminopyridines, aldehydes and alkynoic acids. The catalysts were prepared and characterized by FESEM/EDS, FT-IR and TGA. FESEM-EDS analysis depicted the presence of Cu, S, O, C and N (Fig. 2 (i)) in chit@CuSO4 catalyst. The FESEM-EDS elemental map was recorded at a selected region of chit@CuSO4 catalyst which clearly represent the dispersity of C, O, S, Cu and N on the surface of chitosan (Fig. 2(ii)). TGA analysis revealed that chit@CuSO4 was thermally stable up to 200 °C. However, an initial weight loss at temperature below 100 °C was observed in both chitosan and chit@CuSO4 due to physically adsorbed water on chitosan surface (see, SI). We commenced our study on the model reaction between 2-aminopyridine (1a), p-chlorobenzaldehyde (2a) and phenylpropiolic acid (3a) under solventless conditions at 140 °C (Table 1 ). Among various chit@Cu(I) and chit@Cu(II) catalysts screened for this reaction (entries 1–5, Table 1), chit@Cu(II) proved better. Thus, chit@CuSO4 (10 mg) provided 4a in 52% yield (entry 5) as compared to less than 7% yield using chit@CuI after 7 h (entry 1). Thereafter, role of various additives along with chit@CuSO4 (entry 6–11) was evaluated. Initially, we explored ionic liquids (ILs) alongwith chit@CuSO4 since ILs are known to catalyze decarboxylation reactions [53]. However, the product was detected in traces when [bmim]Br (neutral) and [bmim]OH (basic) ILs were used as additives (entries 6 & 7). Similarly, the use of chitosan-ionic liquid supported FeCl3 (5) [51,55] or its precursor 6 as additives, provided 4a only in 25% and <10% yield respectively (entry 8 & 9). Also, the use of PPh3 or NaHSO4/SiO2 along with chit@CuSO4 proved futile (entries 10 & 11). Thereafter, we decided to test the mixed Cu(I)-Cu(II) system, as some research groups have reported such combination in A3-type coupling reactions [27,45,46]. Thus, catalytic combination of chit@CuSO4-chit@CuCl (10 mg each) could improve the yield of 4a only upto 58% (entry 12, Table 1). In particular, initial mixing of 1a and 2a (120 °C, 2 h) followed by addition of 3a in the same pot significantly improved the yield of 4a (67% yield) at 140 °C in 7 h (entry 13). Furthermore, after 16 h of reaction time, the product was obtained in 78% yield, however no further improvement in the yield was observed after prolonged heating upto 24 h (entry 14). Surprisingly, 4a was obtained in 79% yield by using chit@CuSO4 alone with enhanced amount of 20 mg at 140 °C (entry 15), suggesting no need of using mixed Cu(I)-Cu(II) catalytic system. Almost the same yield of 4a was obtained when the reaction temperature was reduced to 120 °C (entry 16). We decided to add 4 Å molecular sieves along with chit@CuSO4 (20 mg) to remove the water released from the condensation step and improved yield of 4a (84%) was obtained (entry 17). No further improvement in the yield was observed by increasing the catalyst amount or changing the substrates’ molar ratio (entries 18 & 19). The compatibility of chit@CuSO4 catalyst with various solvents (entries 20–22) was also explored. Toluene provided a better yield of product (79%) as compared to ethanol (69%) or acetonitrile (74%), however, solventless condition was found to be optimum (entry 17). With the optimized reaction conditions in hand, we further examined the scope and limitations of the reaction by using a variety of aldehydes along with 2-aminopyridines and phenylpropiolic acids (Table 2 ). A wide range of benzaldehydes possessing electron-donating groups (OMe, Me, i Pr) and electron-withdrawing groups (CN, Cl, Br, F) responded well. Sterically hindered benzaldehydes like 3,4,5-trimethoxybenzaldehyde (2e) and 3,4-dimethoxybenzaldehyde (2f) were found compatible under the developed conditions. In addition, heteroaldehyde such as furfuraldehyde could be successfully employed as coupling partner and provided the products 4i and 4j in good yields. However, reaction of nitrobenzaldehyde (possessing a strong electron-withdrawing -NO2 group) resulted in multiple side products and the desired product (4v) could not be isolated. Similarly, the reaction with aliphatic aldehydes could not proceed. On the other side, various substituents on 2-aminopyridine such as 5-Me, 5-Cl provided the corresponding products (4e, 4h-4l, 4n-4o) in high yields. Phenylpropiolic acids substituted with methyl or fluoro group responded well (4s & 4t). However, reactions with aliphatic acids i.e. butynoic acid and cyclopropylpropynoic acid, could not proceed, probably due to their inability towards decarboxylation. The broad substrate scope including compatibility with Br and Cl substituents offers the possibility of further functionalization of imidazopyridines into biologically relevant molecules through various cross-coupling strategies. In particular, this methodology provided an efficient route for the synthesis of analogues of zolimidine (4k-4m), an antiulcer drug in clinical practice. 3 Computational studies With an intention to evaluate the role of Cu(I) & Cu(II) based catalysts in different steps of this reaction, we planned to carry out a detailed theoretical study. DFT calculations were performed using ORCA quantum chemistry program 4.1 [56]. The initial reaction between 2-aminopyridine (1a) and benzaldehyde (2c) can generate imine (2d) via two pathways; (i) direct nucleophilic addition of 1a to 2c, (ii) facilitated by the acidic proton of phenylpropiolic acid (3a) (Scheme 2 ). From the DFT calculations, it was found that the protonation of 2c with the acidic proton of 3a is a thermodynamically unfavorable step (ΔG = 72 kcal/mol) because of the formation of charged species; protonated aldehyde and acid salt 3a'. On the other hand, direct nucleophilic addition of 1a to 2c followed by elimination of water give imine (2d) in a slightly endergonic fashion (6 kcal/mol). Calculated energy suggested that this path is reversible and all the species remain in equilibrium. Also, the removal of water or consumption of 2d in the next step favors forward reaction (Scheme 2). Overall this step is not significant in view of kinetic or thermodynamic control of formation of final product. In the next step, reaction of imine (2d) with 3a can lead to the formation of propargylamine i.e. uncyclized decarboxylative A3-product (8, Scheme 3 ). For evaluating the role of Cu(I) and Cu(II) catalytic systems for this decarboxylative A3-coupling step, it was assumed that Cu ions remain coordinated in chitosan framework and counter ions do not play significant role. Hence, dissociation energy of copper salt was neglected in calculations to find out the favourable reaction pathways. Also, chit@Cu (I/II) species were considered as starting materials and their free energy was taken as zero for reference. The reaction of phenylpropiolic acid (3a) with chit@Cu(I) and chit@Cu(II) delivered 6a and 6b respectively (Scheme 3). Energetically, 6b (−28 kcal/mol) was found to be more stable than 6a (+47 kcal/mol), and the optimized geometries shows that Cu(II) strongly interact with 3 (Scheme 3). Both 6a and 6b underwent decarboxylation to generate corresponding copper-acetylide species 7a and 7b respectively. 6a faces a high free energy barrier (TS1a, +63 kcal/mol) for the formation of 7a as compared to 6b (TS1b, −12 kcal/mol) towards formation of 7b. Thus, the calculated free energy barriers indicated that Cu(II) play a more significant role in the decarboxylation (15 kcal/mol) step as compared to Cu(I). Possibly, higher positive charge and greater electronegativity of Cu(II) makes it a better candidate for this step. In the next step, the addition of 7b (−59 kcal/mol) to imine (2d) results in the formation of propargylamine 8 (−2 kcal/mol). Our theoretical calculations suggested that the formation of desired imidazopyridine 4c from 8 using both Cu(I) or Cu(II) can occur via high energy barriers TS2a (141 kcal/mol) and TS2b (112 kcal/mol) which suggested that Cu species may not play any specific role. The Gibbs-free energy profile for the formation of 4c using chit@Cu(I) and chit@Cu(II) catalyst via cyclization of 8 is described in Scheme 3. In order to find out the actual intermediates involved during the transformation of 8 into 4c, all the possible species/isomers 9 to 13 were predicted and their stability was calculated (Scheme 4 ). Among these, an allene type of species 10 was found to be favourably more stable (−9 kcal/mol), possibly formed from 8 via 1,3-proton transfer isomerization. alkyne-allene isomerization [57,58] can proceed through concerted or stepwise mechanism involving discrete anionic intermediate. However, we could not find the transition state or intermediate corresponding to this 1,3-proton transfer. Deprotonation at the propargylic position of 8 is not a difficult step as the propargyl anion 9 is stabilized by charge delocalization into nearby three aromatic systems. Transfer of proton from 8 to form allene intermediate 10 (via deprotonation-protonation) is an exergonic reaction (ΔG = −7 kcal/mol). Subsequently, species 10 converts to the final product 4c through 11 (negligible barrier) and transition state, TS3 (12 kcal/mol). These results suggested that one of the protons at the benzylic position of product 4c might come from aldehyde. This is further supported by the reaction of deuterated benzaldehyde (C6H5CDO) with 2-aminopyridine and phenylacetylene resulting in imidazopyridine deuterated at the benzylic position. 3.1 Control experiments A number of controlled experiments were performed to further explore the mechanistic aspects of the reaction. The incipient decarboxylative A3-product i.e. propargylamine intermediate (8) could be monitored on TLC plate and was found to undergo rapid conversion as soon as it is generated. Also, it could be detected by mass analysis (m/z = 284 and ion fragments at 191, 207) of the aliquots taken from the reaction mixture at different time intervals. For control experiments, we synthesized 8 on large scale using a known procedure [59]. To our uttermost surprise, treatment of 8 at 120 °C in toluene successfully afforded corresponding imidazopyridine (4c, 35%, 8 h) without the need of any metal catalyst (eqn. 1, Scheme 5 ), which is consistent with the DFT calculations. Further, addition of a base Cs2CO3 significantly accelerated the rate of the reaction (eqn. 2, Scheme 5). It is a clear evidence that Cs2CO3 might be assisting abstraction of propargylic proton and thus isomerization to corresponding allene intermediate [60] seems reasonable. Furthermore, 8 could be cyclized to 4c under neat conditions (without solvent and base) at 120 °C (eqn. 3, Scheme 5). Based on the DFT calculations and experimental investigations, the plausible mechanism for the formation of imidazopyridine (4c) is given in Scheme 6 . Initially, an imine intermediate (2d) is formed by the reaction between 2-aminopyridine and benzaldehyde. Subsequently, a copper-acetylide species (7b), generated via chit@CuSO4-promoted decarboxylation of phenylpropiolic acid (3a), undergoes addition with 2d to provide the corresponding A3-product i.e. propargylamine (8). Finally, a metal-free prototropic isomerization of incipient 8 followed by cyclization transforms it into the desired imidazopyridine (4c). This transformation occurs through the involvement of allene type intermediates (10 & 11) and a transition state denoted as TS3 (Scheme 6). The recyclability of chit@CuSO4 catalyst was also examined by carrying out the model reaction between 1a, 2a and 3a under optimized reaction conditions (Table 1, entry 17). After the reaction, ethyl acetate was added to the reaction mixture and both catalyst and MS were separated by simple filtration. The catalyst was washed with ethyl acetate and dried under reduced pressure. The isolated catalyst was redispersed to the reaction mixture for the next cycle under the same reaction conditions and reused for subsequent cycles. The catalyst was found to be recyclable upto five cycles to afford 4a in 84, 82%, 81%, 78%, 75% (See, SI). 4 Biological evaluation Imidazopyridine and their derivatives are reported to possess antitumor activity against pancreatic, colon and breast cancer cells [61–63]. In this study, some of the synthesized imidazo[1,2-a]pyridines were investigated for their antiproliferative activity against human neuroblastoma (SHSY-5Y) cells using standard MTT assay at 5, 10 and 25 µM concentration (Table 3 ). The results were analysed after 48 h of drug treatment. It was found that compound 4a, 4d with IC50 value of 7.63±0.10 µM, 9.14±0.32 µM, respectively showed better antiproliferative activity as compared to reference gefitinib. Thus, this series of compounds exhibited good activity against SHSY-5Y cells and their screening against other cancer cell lines is under progress. 5 Conclusions We have developed an efficient protocol for the synthesis of imidazo[1,2-a]pyridines via multicomponent decarboxylative coupling of 2-aminopyridines, aldehydes and alkynoic acids using recyclable chit@CuSO4 catalyst. The detailed DFT/mechanistic studies revealed the involvement of allene intermediate, formed via prototropic isomerization of in-situ generated propargylamine. It was found that decarboxylative A3-coupling step for the propargylamine formation is facilitated by chit@Cu(II) catalyst whereas its isomerization to allene and further cyclization to the desired imidazopyridines is possible under metal-free conditions. Furthermore, the synthesized imidazo[1,2-a]pyridines showed some interesting antiproliferative activity against human neuroblastoma (SHSY-5Y) cells. 6 Experimental section 6.1 General procedure for the synthesis of imidazo[1,2-a]pyridines (4a-4t). coredata.dc:description: An efficient multicomponent decarboxylative coupling of 2-aminopyridines, aldehydes and alkynoic acids for the synthesis of imidazo[1,2-a]pyridines was developed using recyclable chitosan-supported copper (chit@CuSO4) as a heterogeneous catalyst. Computational and experimental evidence revealed that in situ generated propargylamine undergoes cyclization to the desired imidazopyridine via prototropic isomerization involving allene type intermediates. Control experiments on isolated propargylamine demonstrated that cyclization could proceed without any metal catalyst. In literature, the cyclization step is assumed to be facilitated by metal catalyst and experimental proof for the involvement of actual intermediates is not available. The synthesized imidazopyridines were further evaluated for antiproliferative activity against human neuroblastoma cells (SHSY-5Y) using MTT assay.
coredata.dc:title: Efficient synthesis and mechanistic insights for the formation of imidazo[1,2-a]pyridines via multicomponent decarboxylative coupling using chitosan-supported copper catalysts
